newsitem.title: ECUADOR: Ecuador to appeal U.S. ruling favoring Texaco.
newsitem.headline: Ecuador to appeal U.S. ruling favoring Texaco.

text.p: Ecuador will appeal a U.S. court ruling that dismissed a class-action suit against Texaco Inc for alleged environmental damage in the Andean nation, a prosecutor said Monday.

"In my role as state prosecutor, I will defend the position of the natives and of the country so that it does not continue to be destroyed by Texaco and so many international companies that come and loot Ecuador and cause us harm," Leonidas Plaza told reporters.
Plaza said he was acting at the request of Ecuadoran legislators and indigenous groups.

Last week, a U.S. federal judge said the United States was not the appropriate forum for the case, in which a group of Ecuadorans accused Texaco of failing to protect the environment during the company's 28 years operating in the region.
The ruling upheld an earlier U.S. decision to dismiss the case on the same grounds.

In last week's U.S. ruling, the judge said the plaintiffs' failure to bring the case against Ecuador's state oil company and the Ecuadorean government, along with Texaco, was another cause for dismissal, as they also participated in the operations that allegedly led to the environmental damage. Sovereign immunity protects the Ecuadoran participants from such action.
Texaco operated in Ecuador from 1964 to 1992, producing a peak 220,000 barrels per day of oil.
In 1994, the company signed an accord to shut abandoned wells and pits, and revegetate the land. Work is due to be completed in December.
